Today‚Äôs decision is yet another example of how a corrupted Supreme Court, captured by Special Interests and big donors, is turning back the clock on our rights. The Court is broken. It üëè must üëè be üëè reformed!

We have a moral & legal responsibility to Tribes to provide life sustaining waters promised by the trust & treaty responsibilities of the U.S. In Congress, I will never stop fighting to protect the rights of Indigenous nations &  their rights to water as I have my entire career.

The treaty of 1868 promised the Navajo Nation a ‚Äúpermanent home.‚Äù A home without water is a promise broken. And when Justices Kavanaugh, Roberts, Thomas, Alito, & Barrett turn on their tap tonight, I hope they think of the 170,000 Navajo citizens who live that broken promise.
The federal government has a legal and moral duty to protect the rights and provide water to Tribal Nations, and this decision is a shameful turning back of the clock on that promise.

Today the Court‚Äôs extremist majority ruled that the U.S. does not have an explicit trust responsibility to secure water for Tribal nations unless spelled out in treaty, undercutting the very foundation of the Winters Doctrine laid out in 1908 & litigated over the last 115 years.

The 1908 Winters decision by the Supreme Court established that tribal lands that were reserved by treaty or other federal actions also carried water rights to provide a sustainable homeland. Since then, the Winters decision has been the standard for tribal water rights.

America‚Äôs schools should be centers for learning and growth, NOT hotels for people pouring across our southern border.

@HouseGOP #BidenBorderCrisis
Here‚Äôs the deal: Nearly 40% of Navajo families do not have access to water in their homes, and in some parts of the Navajo Nation, 91% of Navajo households lack access to water.

Let me be clear: This doesn‚Äôt just impact the Navajo Nation; it could impact water rights and access across Indian Country. It is a direct affront to Tribal rights, the federal trust responsibility, and 115 years of settled law under the Winters Doctrine.

This SHAMEFUL decision upends more than a hundred years of legal precedent at the expense of Tribal water rights and the Trust Responsibility.
